Federated Learning in UAV-Enhanced Networks: Joint Coverage and Convergence Time Optimization

Mariam Yahya, Setareh Maghsudi, and Slawomir Stanczak
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) involves several devices that collaboratively train a shared model without transferring their local data. FL reduces the communication overhead, making it a promising learning method in UAV-enhanced wireless networks with scarce energy resources. Despite the potential, implementing FL in UAV-enhanced networks is challenging, as conventional UAV placement methods that maximize coverage increase the FL delay significantly. Moreover, the uncertainty and lack of a priori information about crucial variables, such as channel quality, exacerbate the problem. In this paper, we first analyze the statistical characteristics of a UAV-enhanced wireless sensor network (WSN) with energy harvesting. We then develop a model and solution based on the multi-objective multi-armed bandit theory to maximize the network coverage while minimizing the FL delay. Besides, we propose another solution that is particularly useful with large action sets and strict energy constraints at the UAVs. Our proposal uses a scalarized best-arm identification algorithm to find the optimal arms that maximize the ratio of the expected reward to the expected energy cost by sequentially eliminating one or more arms in each round. Then, we derive the upper bound on the error probability of our multi-objective and cost-aware algorithm. Numerical results show the effectiveness of our approach. ††footnotetext: Parts of this paper were presented at the European Wireless Conference, Dresden, Germany in September 2022 [1]. M. Index Terms:
Federated learning, unmanned aerial vehicles, coverage, convergence time, multi-objective multi-armed bandits.

I Introduction

The advances in the hardware for on-device intelligence enable unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to offer computation-intensive services based on machine learning methods, such as image classification [2] and smart agriculture [3]. Implementing centralized machine learning methods in UAV networks is often infeasible due to the requirement of transferring large data volumes and privacy hazards. To mitigate such shortcomings, federated learning (FL) has emerged as an alternative learning paradigm in UAV-enhanced networks.
FL is a distributed learning algorithm that preserves the clients’ privacy and reduces communication costs by training a shared model mainly locally in the clients without sharing their raw data. In each global iteration, the server transmits the global model to the clients to update it using their local data. Then, they send the updated local models to the server that aggregates them to start a new iteration. This iterative process of transmitting and updating the models continues until achieving the desired global accuracy [4]. FL facilitates various applications and services in UAV-enhanced networks. These include communication, network management, and computation offloading [5].
One major challenge of FL is the potentially lengthy convergence, which stems from (i) the prolonged transmission time of the local and global updates over the wireless channels, (ii) the computation delays at the FL clients to update the local models, and (iii) the iterative global updates. There are different methods to address this issue, such as client selection [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11], resource allocation (RA) [12, 13], and update compression [14]. Client selection is one of the most common approaches for reducing the FL convergence time. It selects the clients that lead to faster convergence to participate in FL, which makes it particularly useful in networks with many clients and a few channels. The CS criteria often depend on the client’s communication- and computation delays in each global iteration [10], the clients’ local losses [9], or their data type [15]. To ensure the clients’ participation in FL training, [7, 8, 10, 9] tackle the fairness issue in CS. Alternatively, Dinh et al [12] use the resource allocation approach to balance two conflicting objectives, minimizing the FL time and reducing the energy consumption. Convergence time minimization is a crucial research topic also in UAV-enhanced networks [13, 16]. The authors in [13] design a joint power allocation and scheduling scheme for a UAV swarm to optimize the FL convergence while controlling energy consumption. Finally, asynchronous FL schemes shorten the convergence time [16] as the servers do not wait for all local updates.
Another major challenge to optimizing the FL performance is the uncertainty due to the randomness and lack of information, for example, in channel qualities, resource availability, and network density or topology. Even though the channel state information and the variables above are unavailable in realistic scenarios, the majority of the cutting-edge research assumes otherwise [12, 13, 16]. Still, a few works use machine learning-based methods to overcome this challenge. The most relevant example to our work example is the multi-armed bandit (MAB) framework, where the network manager learns the network’s statistical information sequentially during the FL training process [8, 7, 9, 10, 11, 17]. More details on the MAB framework is given in Section I-B. Table I summarizes the most relevant state-of-the-research.

Thanks to their flexibility and low cost, UAVs integrate well into 5G, 6G, and internet-of-things (IoT) networks as aerial base stations to improve their performance and enable new applications [3, 13, 18, 16, 19, 20, 21]. For example, UAVs are used in private content caching while ensuring age-of-information aware, fair, and energy-efficient content delivery [19]. In such applications, ML methods are widely applicable. For example, deep neural networks predict the mobile users’ locations to perform UAV-network slicing to guarantee coverage and the ultra-reliable low latency communications (URLLC) requirements of control signals [20]. Moreover, using deep reinforcement learning, one can optimize the phase shifts of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces for energy harvesting [21] and the energy efficiency of blockchain operations in UAV-assisted computation offloading in IoT networks [22]. In this paper, we optimize the performance of a FL UAV-enhanced network under high uncertainty and conflicting objectives using MABs.

I-A Motivation

As described above, the UAVs might engage in an FL procedure, each using the data collected locally in its coverage area [23], one significant example appears in IoT for agriculture for crop monitoring, fertilizer management, and data collection [3]. In such a scenario, the UAVs’ placement and coverage substantially affect the FL convergence time, an issue that remains unaddressed to a great extent. The conventional approaches of UAV placement for coverage maximization prolong the FL convergence delay drastically due to the inhomogeneous sensor- or user-density in the UAVs’ coverage area. Larger data volumes often require more processing time, so the FL server waits longer for slower UAVs that cover dense locations to update the global model. Such a straggler effect increases the overall delay. In [18], we proposed an approach to jointly maximize the network coverage and minimize the FL convergence time by effective UAVs’ placement and radio resource management. The UAVs’ placement ensured higher homogeneity in the number of sensors covered by each UAV, thus, similar processing times.
This paper proposes a novel method to jointly maximize the sensor coverage and minimize the FL convergence time in a UAV-enhanced network under uncertainty about the sensors’ distribution and channels’ quality. It also considers the non-deterministic sensors’ activity due to opportunistic energy harvesting. The two objectives are conflicting since increasing the sensor coverage results in heavier computation and extended delays. To solve this problem under uncertainty, we use a multi-objective multi-armed bandits (MO-MAB) framework [24] merged as an alternative learning paradigm in UAV networks. With this approach, we provide a solution for a realistic UAV network that is robust to information shortage.

I-B MO-MAB as a Solution Framework

MAB is an online sequential decision-making problem where, in each round, an agent selects an arm from a set to receive a reward sampled from its apriori unknown reward-generating process. The agent intends to choose the arms to minimize its long-term cumulative regret [25]. In the multi-objective version of the MAB problem, each arm returns a reward vector, where each element is the reward of the corresponding objective [24]. Since there are multiple objectives, there can be several optimal reward vectors, thus, several optimal arms [24], [26]. Hence the agent aims to simultaneously minimize the regret in all objectives by playing optimal arms fairly.
Drugan et al. proposed two ways to obtain the set of optimal arms in a MO-MAB problem: the Pareto partial order approach and the scalarization approach [24]. The former maximizes the reward vectors directly in the multi-objective reward space by looking at the dominance relationships between arms, while the latter uses a set of appropriate scalarization functions to transform the multi-objective problem into a single objective one and find the optimal arms. In this paper, we solve our bi-objective problem of coverage maximization and convergence time minimization using both approaches and compare their performance.
One challenge in our problem formulation is the large number of arms. In addition, the scalarized multi-objective approach requires finding the optimal arm for each scalarization function. To address these issues, we develop an algorithmic solution to our bi-objective optimization problem based on the best-arm identification (BAI) algorithm [27]. The fixed-budget BAI algorithm aims at finding the optimal arm with high probability in a fixed number of rounds [27, 28]. Consequently, the algorithm’s performance does not concern the cumulative regret but the quality of the final recommendation, i.e., the probability that the recommended arm is optimal.
In each round, the general sequential elimination algorithm [28] eliminates one [27, 29] or more arms with the lowest average rewards, allowing the algorithm to scale well with the increasing number of arms (see Table 1 in [28]). Our proposed solution extends that algorithm to the multi-objective scenario with one crucial adjustment: the optimal arm is defined as the one that maximizes the ratio of the expected reward obtained from selecting an arm to the incurred cost. This cost depends on the network coverage and transmission delays and accounts for the random energy consumed by the UAVs in updating and transmitting the local models. Therefore, the proposed algorithm differs from the approach in [30] that eliminates one arm per round assuming that the reward and cost are independent. Then, we find an upper bound on the error probability for our proposed algorithm. The fixed budget setting of the proposed algorithm allows us to estimate the required energy of the solution.

I-C Our Contributions

This paper considers a UAV-enhanced WSN in which the UAVs collect sensor data and engage in FL with a ground server. It addresses the problem of UAV placement, aiming to simultaneously maximize the network coverage and minimize the FL convergence delay under high uncertainty about the sensors’ placement, activity, and channel conditions. As these two objectives are conflicting, this paper proposes solutions based on bi-objective-MABs (BO-MABs). The following list outlines the key contributions.

  • •

    Analyzing the components of the FL time and obtaining their statistical distributions.

  • •

    Formulating the problem as an optimization problem with two conflicting objectives: maximizing the sensor coverage, and minimizing the total FL delay.

  • •

    Modelling and solving the problem in a BO-MAB framework using both the Pareto partial ordering and scalarization. Then, the simulation results for the two methods are presented.

  • •

    Given the possibility of having many arms and the limited energy resources at the UAVs, the paper proposes a scalarization-based sequential elimination algorithm for BAI for the BO-MAB scheme. In this algorithm, the best arm is defined as the one that maximizes the ratio of the expected reward to the expected energy cost for an energy-efficient solution. Afterward, an upper bound to the error probability is derived for the proposed algorithm.

  • •

    The proposed algorithm is used to find the UAV configuration that achieves the best coverage and convergence delay per energy cost. The numerical results show the algorithm’s performance for an FL network training the MNIST dataset for image classification.

I-D Paper Organization

Section II presents the system model. Section III, analyzes the FL convergence time and shows the dependency of the convergence time on the network coverage. In Section IV, the problem is formulated as a bi-objective optimization problem. Then, in Section V, the multi-objective MAB problem is described and then is used in Section VI to solve the joint problem of coverage maximization and convergence time minimization. In Section VII, a computationally efficient solution is proposed using a scalarization-based sequential elimination algorithm for best arm identification. Section VIII includes the numerical results and Section IX concludes.

II System Model

The system model illustrated in Fig. 1. In this WSN, the sensors are located randomly in a square region of edge length E𝐸E. The sensors’ locations and density distribution are unknown to the UAVs and the ground server. All the sensors are homogeneous in their transmit power and data size, and each sensor relies on ambient energy harvesting to operate. The network also includes a set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} of U𝑈U rotary-wing UAVs with identical computation capabilities. Each sensor collects data and transmits it to a UAV; thus, a sensor communicates with a UAV if (i) it is within that UAV’s coverage region and (ii) it has sufficient energy. Due to the random nature of energy harvesting, the number of transmitting sensors (active) at a given time is random. Each UAV collects data from the active sensors in its coverage region and engages in the FL process with the ground server over a dedicated communication link. This system was motivated by many applications such as the IoT for agriculture and natural disaster analysis. The proposed framework is easily adaptable to other system models as long as network delay and coverage remain uncertain. The first arises due to the randomness in the communication delays and the UAVs’ processing capabilities, whereas the latter arises by the randomness in the number of sensors or their availability.

In brief, each global iteration m𝑚m of FEDL starts when the ground server transmits a model to the UAVs. However, since F​(𝝎∗)𝐹superscript𝝎F(\boldsymbol{\omega}^{*}) is unknown to the server, the algorithm stops after a predetermined number of global iterations.

II-B Transmission Probability of Energy Harvesting Sensors

The wireless sensors obtain their required energy via ambient energy harvesting, a convenient energy resource in IoT in agriculture [3]. The sensor use a harvest-use scheme. A sensor transmits its data to a UAV only if it lies in its coverage region and has sufficient transmission energy. And since ambient energy harvesting is non-deterministic, the sensors’ activity is random
We model the energy arrival process at a sensor m𝑚m as a Poisson process with the rate λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m}. The amount of energy harvested in each arrival v𝑣v, Zm,vsubscript𝑍𝑚𝑣Z_{m,v}, follows an exponential distribution with parameter ηm,vsubscript𝜂𝑚𝑣\eta_{m,v}, Zm,v∼EXP​(ηm,v)similar-tosubscript𝑍𝑚𝑣EXPsubscript𝜂𝑚𝑣Z_{m,v}{\sim}\text{EXP}(\eta_{m,v}) [31]. The energy harvesting phase continues until the kmsubscript𝑘𝑚k_{m} energy arrival. Afterward, the sensor transmits its data to its corresponding UAV. For known ηm,vsubscript𝜂𝑚𝑣\eta_{m,v}, one can estimate the number of arrivals; otherwise, it can be selected randomly [31]. The total amount of energy at sensor m𝑚m, denoted by Ymsubscript𝑌𝑚Y_{m}, is the sum of kmsubscript𝑘𝑚k_{m} energy arrivals, i.e., Ym=∑v=1kmZm,v.subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑘𝑚subscript𝑍𝑚𝑣Y_{m}=\sum_{v=1}^{k_{m}}Z_{m,v}.

The distribution of Ymsubscript𝑌𝑚Y_{m} for this case is given in [31] along with the conditions required for approximating the distribution of Ymsubscript𝑌𝑚Y_{m} by a Normal or an Erlang distributions.. II-C Network Coverage

The network coverage can be maximized by finding the optimal locations of the UAVs in the 3D space and then relocating the UAVs accordingly. However, this approach is computationally costly and power inefficient. In addition, given no information about the sensor’s deployment density, it is infeasible to find the optimal UAV placement that maximizes the sensor coverage. To overcome these problems, the UAVs are deployed according to the circle packing theorem in the 2D space and retain a fixed altitude H𝐻H.222Our work applies to the case where the sensor’s distribution is known, but their availability is random. In this case, other initial UAV placements might suit better than CS. Then, the coverage of the UAVs is controlled by adjusting the beamwidth of each UAV while maintaining its location. Details follow.
Each UAV i𝑖i has a directional antenna with an adjustable beamwidth. Similar to [32], the azimuth and elevation half-power beamwidths of the antennas are assumed to be the same and equal to θi∈(0,π2)subscript𝜃𝑖0𝜋2\theta_{i}\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2}) in radians. The approximate antenna gain is [33]

where G0=2.2846subscript𝐺02.2846G_{0}=2.2846 [32], and g0subscript𝑔0g_{0} is the gain in the side lobes. In practice, we have 0<g0≪G0/θi20subscript𝑔0much-less-thansubscript𝐺0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖20<g_{0}\ll G_{0}/\theta_{i}^{2}. The maximum beamwidth θi,maxsubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i,\max} of UAV i𝑖i is determined by the minimum acceptable receive power Pr,minsubscript𝑃r,minP_{\text{r,min}} at UAV i𝑖i defined to be

where Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\text{t}} is the power transmitted by a wireless sensor and it is equal for all sensors. (13)

III The FL Convergence Time and Its Dependency on Coverage

In the proposed UAV-enhanced network, the FL convergence time has three main components:

  • •

    The local model update time at the UAVs (computation time);

  • •

    The data transmission time between the sensors and the UAVs ;

  • •

    The local- and global model exchange time between the UAVs and the server.

Changing a UAV’s beamwidth influences the number of its covered sensors, hence the number of its collected data samples and its model update time. In addition, the communication time over the sensor-UAV link depends on the beamwidth because it affects the distance between the sensor and the UAV and so the channel quality. More precisely, larger beamwidths worsen the path loss, reduce the antenna gain, and prolong the communication delays. In contrast, the communication delay between each UAV and the server depends on the length and quality of the UAV-server communication link.

III-A Computation Time

The beamwidth of UAV i𝑖i, θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, determines the number of active sensors it covers and with it, the number of data samples Di,θisubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖D_{i,\theta_{i}} it processes. Given that the sensors sample at the same frequency, i.e., there are D𝐷D samples per sensor, the average computation time of UAV i𝑖i yields

Ti,θicp=I​(κ)​δ​Di,θifCPU=I​(κ)​δ​D​N¯i,θifCPU,subscriptsuperscript𝑇cp𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝐼𝜅𝛿subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑓CPU𝐼𝜅𝛿𝐷subscript¯𝑁𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑓CPUT^{\text{cp}}_{i,\theta_{i}}=I(\kappa)\frac{\delta D_{i,\theta_{i}}}{f_{\text{CPU}}}=I(\kappa)\frac{\delta D\bar{N}_{i,\theta_{i}}}{f_{\text{CPU}}}, (14)

where N¯i,θisubscript¯𝑁𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖\bar{N}_{i,\theta_{i}} is the average number of active nodes given by (13). That shows that a large beamwidth can result in a high computation time by increasing the coverage. To simplify the derivation of the delay probability distribution, the UAVs’ CPU frequency fCPUsubscript𝑓CPUf_{\text{CPU}} is assumed to be constant. The amount of energy consumed by UAV i𝑖i in updating its local model is

Ei,θicp=α2​I​(κ)​δ​Di,θi​fCPU2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cp𝛼2𝐼𝜅𝛿subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑓2CPUE_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}}=\frac{\alpha}{2}I(\kappa)\delta D_{i,\theta_{i}}f^{2}_{\text{CPU}}, (15)

where α𝛼\alpha is the energy capacitance coefficient of the UAVs.
The following proposition gives the probability distribution function of the computation time at UAV i𝑖i for the Poisson nodes’ distribution. The value of Ti,θicpsubscriptsuperscript𝑇cp𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖T^{\text{cp}}_{i,\theta_{i}} in (14) is an integer multiple τ𝜏\tau of I​(κ)​δ​DfCPU𝐼𝜅𝛿𝐷subscript𝑓CPUI(\kappa)\frac{\delta D}{f_{\text{CPU}}}. The mean computation time at the UAV per unit of coverage area is ν=I​(κ)​δ​D​λfCPU𝜈𝐼𝜅𝛿𝐷𝜆subscript𝑓CPU\nu=I(\kappa)\frac{\delta D\lambda}{f_{\text{CPU}}} second/m2, where λ𝜆\lambda is the sensor density. The probability distribution function of the computation time at UAV i𝑖i, Ti,θicpsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cpT_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}} is

ℙ​[Ti,θicp=τ​(I​(κ)​δ​DfCPU)]=(ν​Ωi,θi)τ​e−(ν​Ωi,θi)τ!​∑n=0km−11n!​e−ηm​ET​(ηm​ET)n,τ=0,1,2,…formulae-sequenceℙdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cp𝜏𝐼𝜅𝛿𝐷subscript𝑓CPUsuperscript𝜈subscriptΩ𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝜏superscript𝑒𝜈subscriptΩ𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑘𝑚11𝑛superscript𝑒subscript𝜂𝑚subscript𝐸Tsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑚subscript𝐸T𝑛𝜏012…\mathbb{P}\left[T_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}}=\tau\left(I(\kappa)\frac{\delta D}{f_{\text{CPU}}}\right)\right]=\frac{(\nu\Omega_{i,\theta_{i}})^{\tau}e^{-(\nu\Omega_{i,\theta_{i}})}}{\tau!}\sum_{n=0}^{{k_{m}}-1}\frac{1}{n!}e^{-\eta_{m}E_{\text{T}}}(\eta_{m}E_{\text{T}})^{n},\quad\tau=0,1,2,\dots (16)

III-B The Communication Time over the UAV-Server Link

As long as a UAV does not move, its link to the ground server and the average delay of the server-UAV communication remains fixed. However, because of the random channel quality, the instantaneous delay can vary. The path loss between UAV i𝑖i and the ground server, denoted Li,GdBsuperscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖GdBL_{i,\text{G}}^{\text{dB}} is obtainable by replacing Ri,θisubscript𝑅𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖R_{i,\theta_{i}} in (10) with di,Gsubscript𝑑𝑖Gd_{i,\text{G}} which represents the horizontal distance between the projection of UAV i𝑖i on the ground and the ground server. The data rate then yields

ri,G=BG​log⁡[1+Pt,G​|gi,G|2​Gi,GLi,G​σG2],subscript𝑟𝑖Gsubscript𝐵G1subscript𝑃t,Gsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖G2subscript𝐺𝑖Gsubscript𝐿𝑖Gsuperscriptsubscript𝜎G2r_{i,\text{G}}=B_{\text{G}}\log\left[1+\frac{P_{\text{t,G}}|g_{i,\text{G}}|^{2}G_{i,\text{G}}}{L_{i,\text{G}}\,\sigma_{\text{G}}^{2}}\right], (17)

where BGsubscript𝐵GB_{\text{G}} is the bandwidth and Pt,Gsubscript𝑃t,GP_{\text{t,G}} is the transmission power of the ground server. Moreover, gi,Gsubscript𝑔𝑖Gg_{i,\text{G}} and Gi,Gsubscript𝐺𝑖GG_{i,\text{G}} respectively denote the gain of the Ricean channel and the antenna gain in the direction of the ground server. Finally, σG2superscriptsubscript𝜎G2\sigma_{\text{G}}^{2} is the noise variance. For the downlink and uplink, we assume equal transmission bandwidths and channel reciprocity. Therefore, the transmission time of the global- and local updates with size SGsubscript𝑆GS_{\text{G}} and SLsubscript𝑆LS_{\text{L}} bits, respectively, is given by

Ti,G=SGri,G,Ti,L=SLri,G.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑖Gsubscript𝑆Gsubscript𝑟𝑖Gsubscript𝑇𝑖Lsubscript𝑆Lsubscript𝑟𝑖GT_{i,\text{G}}=\frac{S_{\text{G}}}{r_{i,\text{G}}},\quad T_{i,\text{L}}=\frac{S_{\text{L}}}{r_{i,\text{G}}}. (18)

The following proposition gives the statistical distribution of the communication time over the UAV-server link for UAV i𝑖i.

Ti,Gsubscript𝑇𝑖GT_{i,\text{G}} is a random variable denoting the communication time of SMsubscript𝑆𝑀S_{M} bits over the UAV-server link, its probability distribution is given by

III-C The Communication Time over the Sensor-UAV Link

Similar to the computation time, the UAVs’ beamwidth affects the communication time over the sensor-UAV link. By increasing the beamwidth, the antenna gain reduces, while the coverage area becomes bigger, implying a potentially longer UAV-sensor distance. Here, the focus is on the delay experienced by the farthest sensor from the projection of the UAV on the ground because it has the highest path loss. Due to the uncertainty in the sensors’ locations, Proposition 20 obtains the expected value of the maximum distance between the UAV and the sensor using the order statistics. Later this value is used in finding the average maximum delay.

Proposition 2.

The average maximum distance between UAV i𝑖i and a sensor located in its coverage region is

Proof.

See Appendix X-B ∎

The sensor’s transmission rate, rZ¯i,θisubscript𝑟subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖r_{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}, yields

where BFsubscript𝐵FB_{\text{F}} is the channel bandwidth and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\text{t}} is the sensor’s transmit power. In addition, gFsubscript𝑔Fg_{\text{F}} denotes the gain of the Ricean channel at the farthest sensor and Gi,θisubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖G_{i,\theta_{i}} is the antenna gain of UAV i𝑖i. σF2superscriptsubscript𝜎F2\sigma_{\text{F}}^{2} is the noise variance. The proof of this proposition is similar to the proof of the distribution of the transmission time over the UAV-server link given by Proposition 1 because the channel has a Ricean distribution in both cases. ∎

III-D The Total FL Convergence Time

The overall communication time is

Ti,θicm=TZ¯i,θi+Ti,G+Ti,L.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cmsubscript𝑇subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖Gsubscript𝑇𝑖LT_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cm}}=T_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}}+T_{i,\text{G}}+T_{i,\text{L}}. (24)

To find the distribution of the communication time, the simplifying assumption of equal sized local and global updates is made to have equal transmission times. A generalization to the uneven case is straightforward. Since the transmission time over the sensor-UAV link tZ¯i,θi>0subscript𝑡subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖0t_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}}>0 is independent from the transmission time over the UAV-server link, ti,G>0subscript𝑡𝑖G0t_{i,\text{G}}>0 the probability distribution of the total communication time tZ¯i,θisubscript𝑡subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖t_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}} is given by their convolution [36]

fTi,θicm​(ti,θicm)=∫0ti,θicmfTZ¯i,θi​(tZ¯i,θi)​fTi,G​(ti,θicm−tZ¯i,θi)​𝑑tZ¯i,θi.subscript𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝑇cm𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑡cm𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript0subscriptsuperscript𝑡cm𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑓subscript𝑇subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑡subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑓subscript𝑇𝑖Gsubscriptsuperscript𝑡cm𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑡subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖differential-dsubscript𝑡subscript¯𝑍𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖f_{T^{\text{cm}}_{i,\theta_{i}}}(t^{\text{cm}}_{i,\theta_{i}})=\int_{0}^{t^{\text{cm}}_{i,\theta_{i}}}f_{T_{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}}(t_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}})f_{T_{i,\text{G}}}(t^{\text{cm}}_{i,\theta_{i}}-t_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}})dt_{{\bar{Z}_{i,\theta_{i}}}}. (25)

The total convergence time is

Ti,θitotal=Ti,θicp+Ti,θicm.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖totalsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cpsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cmT_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{total}}=T_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}}+T_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cm}}. (26)

Finally, Proposition 27 gives the cumulative distribution function of the total delay.

Proposition 4.

The cumulative distribution function of the total delay is

IV Problem Formulation

The server aims at selecting suitable beamwidths for all UAVs that achieve the following conflicting objectives: (i) maximizing the network coverage to incorporate the data of more sensors in FL and (ii) minimizing the time duration of a global iteration.

IV-A Objective 1: Maximizing Coverage

One objective is to maximize the number of sensors uniquely covered by each UAV. That means maximizing the number of active sensors covered by the UAVs while minimizing the overlap between the UAVs’ coverage regions. The problem is challenging as the sensors’ distribution is unknown, and the number of active sensors is a random variable due to the random nature of energy harvesting. Formally,

maximize 𝜽​∑i=1UNi​(θi)−NOL​(𝜽),𝜽maximize superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈subscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑁OL𝜽\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\text{maximize~{}~{}}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}N_{i}(\theta_{i})-N_{\text{OL}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), (28)

where 𝜽={θ1,θ2,…,θU}𝜽subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2…subscript𝜃𝑈\boldsymbol{\theta}=\{\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{U}\} is the set of beamwidths assigned to the UAVs by the server. Ni​(θi)subscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖N_{i}(\theta_{i}) is the number of active sensors covered by UAV i𝑖i when it has beamwidth θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} including the overlapping active sensors that are simultaneously covered by other UAVs. NOLsubscript𝑁OLN_{\text{OL}} is the number of times active sensors are covered simultaneously by more than one UAV.

IV-B Objective 2: Minimizing the Maximum Delay Time

The second objective is to minimize the duration time of one global iteration, as described in Section III. In synchronized FL, the server updates the global model only after receiving the local models of all UAVs. Therefore, the aim is to minimize the maximum update time in a global iteration. That is,

minimize𝜽​[maxi∈𝒰​Ti,θitotal].𝜽minimizedelimited-[]𝑖𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖total\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{\text{minimize}}\,\left[\underset{i\in\mathcal{U}}{\max}\,T_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{total}}\right]. (29)

V Bi-Objective MAB Model

In realistic scenarios, there is often no a priori information about the sensors’ distribution, activity, or the channel quality. Therefore, we propose solving the problem using a bi-objective MAB model.
In proposed model, the decision-maker (bandit agent) is the server, and the action set is the set of UAVs’ beamwidth values. Thus, at every round, the server selects one configuration (arm) for the UAVs from a total of K𝐾K possible configurations, 𝜽k=[θ1,k,θ2,k,…,θU,k]subscript𝜽𝑘subscript𝜃1𝑘subscript𝜃2𝑘…subscript𝜃𝑈𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}=[\theta_{1,k},\theta_{2,k},\dots,\theta_{U,k}] where θi,ksubscript𝜃𝑖𝑘\theta_{i,k} is the beamwidth of UAV i𝑖i when the configuration k𝑘k is selected. Consequently, the server receives a reward vector 𝑿​(𝜽k)=[Xcov​(𝜽k),Xdelay​(𝜽k)]𝑿subscript𝜽𝑘superscript𝑋covsubscript𝜽𝑘superscript𝑋delaysubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{X}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})=[X^{\text{cov}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}),X^{\text{delay}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})] with two elements, one for each objective. The first element of the reward vector concerns coverage so that

Xcov​(𝜽k)=(∑i=1UNi​(θi,k)−NOL​(𝜽k))normalized.superscript𝑋covsubscript𝜽𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈subscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑘subscript𝑁OLsubscript𝜽𝑘normalizedX^{\text{cov}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{U}N_{i}(\theta_{i,k})-N_{\text{OL}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})\right)_{\text{normalized}}. (30)

The second element is related to the total delay, that is,

Xdelay​(𝜽k)=(1maxi∈𝒰​Ti,θi,ktotal)normalized.superscript𝑋delaysubscript𝜽𝑘subscript1𝑖𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖𝑘totalnormalizedX^{\text{delay}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})=\left(\frac{1}{\underset{i\in\mathcal{U}}{\max}\,T_{i,\theta_{i,k}}^{\text{total}}}\right)_{\text{normalized}}. (31)

Let 𝝁k=[μk1,μk2]subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘2\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}=[\mu_{k}^{1},\mu_{k}^{2}] be the expected reward vector of arm k𝑘k. The BO-MAB algorithm must find the optimal arms that maximize the expected reward vector 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}.
The possible values for θi∈[θmin,θmax]subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃subscript𝜃\theta_{i}\in[\theta_{\min},\theta_{\max}] are bounded from above, θmaxsubscript𝜃\theta_{\max}, by the minimum received power at the UAV, as given by (11). Larger upper bounds result in larger coverage areas and a lower received power. At the same time, the difference between the upper- and lower limit determines the level of heterogeneity in the network, which affects the FL performance. In practical systems, θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} takes values on a discrete set of values. Let W𝑊W be the number of beamwidths that the server can select for one UAV; then the total number of arms is

K=WU.𝐾superscript𝑊𝑈K=W^{U}. (32)

For example, in a network with three UAVs, each with two possible angles, the server has 23=8superscript2382^{3}=8 possible configuration choices.

VI Solution for the Bi-Objective MAB Problem

A BO-MAB problem has multiple optimal solutions according to the specified reward vector. The set of reward vectors that are non-dominated by any other reward vectors is the Pareto optimal reward set 𝒪∗superscript𝒪\mathcal{O}^{*}. The arms whose reward vectors belong to 𝒪∗superscript𝒪\mathcal{O}^{*} form the Pareto optimal arm set 𝒜∗superscript𝒜\mathcal{A}^{*} [24]. We use two methods to find optimal solutions for the beamwidth selection problem in Section V: the Pareto and the scalarized upper-confidence-bound 1 (UCB1).

VI-A Pareto UCB1

This algorithm directly maximizes the reward vectors in the two-objective reward space. First, the agent pulls each arm once for initialization. Then, at each iteration, it finds the Pareto optimal arm set 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A^{{}^{\prime}}} that corresponds to the optimal rewards. For all non-optimal arms α∉𝒜′𝛼superscript𝒜′\alpha\not\in\mathcal{A^{{}^{\prime}}}, there exists a Pareto optimal arm k∈𝒜′𝑘superscript𝒜′k\in\mathcal{A^{{}^{\prime}}} that dominates arm α𝛼\alpha, i.e.,

𝑿¯α+2​ln⁡(n​Q​|𝒜∗|4)nα⊁𝑿¯k+2​ln⁡(n​Q​|𝒜∗|4)nknot-succeedssubscript¯𝑿𝛼2𝑛4𝑄superscript𝒜subscript𝑛𝛼subscript¯𝑿𝑘2𝑛4𝑄superscript𝒜subscript𝑛𝑘\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{\alpha}+\sqrt{\frac{2\ln(n\sqrt[4]{Q|\mathcal{A^{*}}|})}{n_{\alpha}}}\not\succ\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{k}+\sqrt{\frac{2\ln(n\sqrt[4]{Q|\mathcal{A^{*}}|})}{n_{k}}} (33)

where 𝑿¯αsubscript¯𝑿𝛼\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{\alpha} is the empirical mean reward of arm α𝛼\alpha, the term 2​ln⁡(n​Q​|𝒜∗|4)nα2𝑛4𝑄superscript𝒜subscript𝑛𝛼\sqrt{\frac{2\ln(n\sqrt[4]{Q|\mathcal{A^{*}}|})}{n_{\alpha}}} is the confidence interval for arm α𝛼\alpha, nαsubscript𝑛𝛼n_{\alpha} is the number of pulls of arm α𝛼\alpha, and Q𝑄Q is the number of objectives, Q=2𝑄2Q=2 here. Since the number of Pareto optimal arms is not known to the player a priori, the term Q​|𝒜∗|44𝑄superscript𝒜\sqrt[4]{Q|\mathcal{A^{*}}|} in (33) can be replaced with Q​K44𝑄𝐾\sqrt[4]{QK} [24]. The notation 𝒖⊁𝒗not-succeeds𝒖𝒗\boldsymbol{u}\not\succ\boldsymbol{v} indicates that the vector 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v} is non-dominated by 𝒖𝒖\boldsymbol{u}, meaning that there exists at least one dimension q𝑞q for which vq>uqsuperscript𝑣𝑞superscript𝑢𝑞v^{q}>u^{q}. After finding the set of optimal arms 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}^{{}^{\prime}}, the algorithm pulls an arm k∈𝒜′𝑘superscript𝒜′k\in\mathcal{A^{{}^{\prime}}} uniformly at random and observes its reward. It then updates its average reward vector 𝑿¯αsubscript¯𝑿𝛼\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{\alpha} and the counters. The process continues until meeting the stopping condition by finding the set of optimal arms.

The performance of the algorithm is measured by the Pareto regret; a measure of the distance between a sub-optimal reward vector 𝝁αsubscript𝝁𝛼\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha} and the Pareto optimal rewards. The Pareto regret of a sub-optimal arm α𝛼\alpha is the minimum positive value ϵαsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon_{\alpha}, denoted ϵα∗subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon^{*}_{\alpha}, that, when added to both objectives, results in a virtual optimal reward vector 𝝂α∗superscriptsubscript𝝂𝛼\boldsymbol{\nu}_{\alpha}^{*} that belongs to the Pareto optimal reward set, i.e, 𝝂α∗=𝝁α+ϵα∗∈𝒪∗superscriptsubscript𝝂𝛼subscript𝝁𝛼subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝛼superscript𝒪\boldsymbol{\nu}_{\alpha}^{*}=\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon}^{*}_{\alpha}\in\mathcal{O}^{*} [24]. The computational complexity for each round of the Pareto UCB1 algorithm is 𝒪​(K​log⁡(K))𝒪𝐾𝐾\mathcal{O}(K\log(K)) [37], this is to find the Pareto set in a bi-objective problem. The overall complexity of the algorithm is 𝒪​(n​K​log⁡(K))𝒪𝑛𝐾𝐾\mathcal{O}(nK\log(K)).

VI-B Scalarized Bi-Objective UCB1

The scalarized bi-objective UCB1 method transfers a bi-objective reward into a single-objective using a scalarization function. To find the Pareto front, a set of S𝑆S scalarization functions to obtain the different elements in the Pareto front set. A widely-considered choice is the linear scalarization (Lin-S) function,

fj​(𝝁k)=ωj1​μk1+ωj2​μk2,∀k∈𝒜,j∈S,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘2formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒜𝑗𝑆f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k})=\omega_{j}^{1}\mu_{k}^{1}+\omega_{j}^{2}\mu_{k}^{2},\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{A},j\in S, (34)

where ωj1,ωj2superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗2\omega_{j}^{1},\omega_{j}^{2} are the weights assigned to the first and second objective under scalarization j𝑗j, such that ωj1+ωj2=1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗21\omega_{j}^{1}+\omega_{j}^{2}=1. The linear function is simple to implement but is incapable of finding all the optimal arms in a non-convex Pareto set [24, 38]. Alternatively, the Chebychev scalarization (Cheb-S) function can, under some conditions, find all the optimal arms in a non-convex Pareto set [38, 24]. The Chebychev scalarization function is given by

fj​(𝝁k)=minq∈{1,2}ωjq​(μkq−zq)∀k∈𝒜,j∈S,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑗𝑞superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑞superscript𝑧𝑞formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒜𝑗𝑆f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k})=\underset{q\in\{1,2\}}{\min}\quad\omega_{j}^{q}(\mu_{k}^{q}-z^{q})\quad\forall k\in\mathcal{A},j\in S, (35)

the reference point zq=min1≤k≤Kμkq−εqsuperscript𝑧𝑞1𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑞superscript𝜀𝑞z^{q}=\underset{1\leq k\leq K}{\min}\quad\mu_{k}^{q}-\varepsilon^{q}, where εqsuperscript𝜀𝑞\varepsilon^{q} is a small positive number, εq>0superscript𝜀𝑞0\varepsilon^{q}>0.
For a given scalarization function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j}, the optimum reward 𝝁∗superscript𝝁\boldsymbol{\mu}^{*} maximizes fj​(𝝁k)superscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}), i.e.,

fj​(𝝁∗)≔max1≤k≤K​fj​(𝝁k).≔superscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝝁1𝑘𝐾superscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}^{*})\coloneqq\underset{1\leq k\leq K}{\max}f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k}). (36)

Algorithm 3 summarizes the scalarized bi-objective UCB1. For each of the scalarization functions fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j}, the agent plays each arm once for initialization. It then updates the counters njsuperscript𝑛𝑗n^{j} for the number of times fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j} is played, and nkjsuperscriptsubscript𝑛𝑘𝑗n_{k}^{j} for the number of times arm k𝑘k is played under scalarization j𝑗j. Afterward, it selects a function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j} uniformly at random, and plays the arm k∗superscript𝑘k^{*} that maximizes the UCB term fj​(𝑿¯k)+2​ln⁡(nj)/nkjsuperscript𝑓𝑗subscript¯𝑿𝑘2superscript𝑛𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑘𝑗f^{j}(\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{k})+\sqrt{2\ln(n^{j})/n_{k}^{j}}. Next, it updates the average reward of arm k𝑘k, 𝑿¯ksubscript¯𝑿𝑘\bar{\boldsymbol{X}}_{k} and the counters.
The regret for scalarization function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j} and sub-optimal arm α𝛼\alpha is the scalarized regret,

Δαj≔max1≤k≤K​fj​(𝝁k)−fj​(𝝁α).≔superscriptsubscriptΔ𝛼𝑗1𝑘𝐾superscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝑘superscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝝁𝛼\Delta_{\alpha}^{j}\coloneqq\underset{1\leq k\leq K}{\max}f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k})-f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha}). (37)

However, this metric does not show the reduction in the bi-objective regret because it combines a set of independent regrets. Thus, we use the unfairness regret to incorporate the mean rewards of all optimal arms [24]

ℜf​(n)=1|𝒜∗|​∑k∈𝒜∗(Tk∗​(n)−𝔼​[T∗​(n)])2,subscriptℜ𝑓𝑛1superscript𝒜subscript𝑘superscript𝒜superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑛2\mathfrak{R}_{f}(n)=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{A}^{*}|}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{A}^{*}}(T_{k}^{*}(n)-\mathbb{E}[T^{*}(n)])^{2}, (38)

where Tk∗​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛T_{k}^{*}(n) is the number of pulls of arm k𝑘k and 𝔼​[T∗​(n)]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑇𝑛\mathbb{E}[T^{*}(n)] is the expected number of times the optimal arms are pulled. The computational complexity for each scalarization function and each round is 𝒪​(K)𝒪𝐾\mathcal{O}(K). Let n𝑛n be the number of times a scalarization function fj∈{f1,…,fS}superscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑓1…superscript𝑓𝑆f^{j}\in\{f^{1},\dots,f^{S}\} is sampled, then the total complexity is 𝒪​(K​S​n)𝒪𝐾𝑆𝑛\mathcal{O}(KSn).

Remark.

The bandit algorithms used in this work are extendable to dynamic environments with non-stationary statistical distributions [39].

VII Sequential Elimination For Scalarization-Based Best Arm Identification

Section VI discussed two methods for solving the bi-objective optimization problem under uncertainty. However, those methods can be inefficient for a large number of UAVs or beamwidths due to the exponential growth in the number of arms, as given in (32). Therefore, this section proposes a novel solution using a generalized BAI algorithm that can control the number of arms eliminated at each round, allowing it to scale well for several arms. To ensure the energy efficiency of the proposed solution, it aims at finding the arm that maximizes the ratio of its expected reward to its expected energy cost. Furthermore, as this algorithm separates the exploration phase from the exploitation phase (pure exploration), the amount of UAV energy consumed during exploration is controlled based on the UAVs’ energy budget.
The proposed algorithm extends the general sequential elimination algorithm for best arm identification in [28] to (i) include the scalarization-based bi-objective MAB algorithm, and (ii) find the arm that maximizes the ratio between the expected reward to the expected cost. The algorithm studies a fixed budget setting, where the agent aims to find the optimal arm with a high probability in a pre-determined number of rounds (budget). It is significant as it generalizes the successive rejects (Succ-Rej) algorithm for identifying the best arm [27] by eliminating one arm in each round of the algorithm. It is also a generalization of the sequential halving (Seq-Halv) algorithm that removes half of the remaining arms in each round [28]. Besides, Shahrampour et. al. develop a new algorithm, namely, non-linear sequential elimination (N-Seq-EL), which extends the Succ-Rej algorithm. Both algorithms eliminate one arm in every round, but the latter divides the remaining budget by a non-linear function of the remaining arms, a trick that can improve the best arm identification probability.
With each arm selection, the server receives 𝑿k=[Xcov​(𝜽k),Xdelay​(𝜽k)]subscript𝑿𝑘superscript𝑋covsubscript𝜽𝑘superscript𝑋delaysubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{X}_{k}=[X^{\text{cov}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}),X^{\text{delay}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k})] a two-dimensional reward vector as defined in (30) and (31), with expected value 𝝁kXsubscriptsuperscript𝝁𝑋𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}^{X}_{k}. Also, this arm selection results in random energy cost cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k}, with mean value μkcsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘\mu^{c}_{k}, affecting both objectives equally. This cost represents the UAV’s consumed energy in updating their local models and transmitting their local updates to the server. It is given by

ck=∑i=1UEi,θicp+Eicm,subscript𝑐𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖cmc_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{U}E_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}}+E_{i}^{\text{cm}}, (39)

where Ei,θicpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖cpE_{i,\theta_{i}}^{\text{cp}} is given in (15), Eicm=Pt,i​Ti,Lsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖cmsubscript𝑃t𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖LE_{i}^{\text{cm}}=P_{\text{t},i}T_{i,\text{L}}, and Pt,isubscript𝑃t𝑖P_{\text{t},i} is the transmit power of UAV i𝑖i.
The server aims to find a beamwidth configuration (arm) k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} that maximizes the ratio of the expected reward to the expected energy cost,

k∗=arg⁡maxk∈{1,…,K}​fj​(𝝁kX)μkc.superscript𝑘𝑘1…𝐾superscript𝑓𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝝁𝑋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘k^{*}=\underset{k\in\{1,\dots,K\}}{\arg\max}\frac{f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\mu}^{X}_{k})}{\mu^{c}_{k}}. (40)

Algorithm 4 summarizes the scalarized cost-aware general sequential elimination (S-C-G-Seq-El) method. It starts by estimating the budget n′superscript𝑛′n^{{}^{\prime}}, i.e., the number of rounds for all scalarization functions, based on the UAV’s energy budget. Let Etotalsubscript𝐸totalE_{\text{total}} be the energy available at a UAV for learning and transmission, i.e., exploration. The fixed budget for running the algorithm is upper bounded by

n′=Etotal|𝒮|​(α2​λ​Ωθmax​D​I​(κ)​δ​fCPU2+Pt​TL,max),superscript𝑛′subscript𝐸total𝒮𝛼2𝜆subscriptΩsubscript𝜃𝐷𝐼𝜅𝛿subscriptsuperscript𝑓2CPUsubscript𝑃tsubscript𝑇Ln^{{}^{\prime}}=\frac{E_{\text{total}}}{|\mathcal{S}|\left(\frac{\alpha}{2}\lambda\Omega_{\theta_{\max}}DI(\kappa)\delta f^{2}_{\text{CPU}}+P_{\text{t}}T_{\text{L},\max}\right)}, (41)

where ΩθmaxsubscriptΩsubscript𝜃\Omega_{\theta_{\max}} is the maximum coverage area of a UAV, and TL,maxsubscript𝑇LT_{\text{L},\max} is the maximum allowed upload time. The denominator in (41) represents the maximum energy consumed by a UAV. It occurs when all the sensors in its coverage region are active and the upload delay is maximized.
After estimating the budget, the S-C-G-Seq-El algorithm proceeds to find the optimal arms 𝑰S∗subscriptsuperscript𝑰𝑆\boldsymbol{I}^{*}_{S} from the Pareto front by identifying the optimal arm for each scalarization function in the set 𝒮={f1,…,fj,…,f|S|}𝒮superscript𝑓1…superscript𝑓𝑗…superscript𝑓𝑆\mathcal{S}=\{f^{1},\dots,f^{j},\dots,f^{|S|}\}. Initially, the set of optimal arms 𝑰S∗subscriptsuperscript𝑰𝑆\boldsymbol{I}^{*}_{S} is empty. Besides, the set of active arms for each scalarization function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j} is the set of all arms 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, formally, 𝑮1j←𝒦←superscriptsubscript𝑮1𝑗𝒦\boldsymbol{G}_{1}^{j}\leftarrow\mathcal{K}. Then for each scalarization function, the algorithm runs for R𝑅R rounds, R=K𝑅𝐾R=K for successive rejects and R=⌈log2⁡K⌉𝑅subscript2𝐾R=\lceil\log_{2}K\rceil in sequential halving. In each round ρ𝜌\rho, it pulls each arm k𝑘k in the set of active arms 𝑮ρjsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝜌𝑗\boldsymbol{G}_{\rho}^{j} for nρ−nρ−1subscript𝑛𝜌subscript𝑛𝜌1n_{\rho}-n_{\rho-1} times,

nρ=⌈n−KC​zρ⌉,ρ=1,…,R,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛𝜌𝑛𝐾𝐶subscript𝑧𝜌𝜌1…𝑅n_{\rho}=\left\lceil\frac{n-K}{Cz_{\rho}}\right\rceil,\quad\rho=1,\dots,R, (42)

where n=⌊n′/|S|⌋𝑛superscript𝑛′𝑆n=\lfloor n^{{}^{\prime}}/|S|\rfloor is the budget for each scalarization function, with n′superscript𝑛′n^{{}^{\prime}} being the total budget. Besides, {zρ}ρ=1Rsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑧𝜌𝜌1𝑅\{z_{\rho}\}_{\rho=1}^{R} is a decreasing positive sequence, and C𝐶C is a constant C=1zR+∑ρ=1Rbρzρ𝐶1subscript𝑧𝑅superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑅subscript𝑏𝜌subscript𝑧𝜌C=\frac{1}{z_{R}}+\sum_{\rho=1}^{R}\frac{b_{\rho}}{z_{\rho}} [28].
After pulling the arms, the algorithm discards the subset 𝑩ρjsuperscriptsubscript𝑩𝜌𝑗\boldsymbol{B}_{\rho}^{j} of bρsubscript𝑏𝜌b_{\rho} arms with the lowest ratio of expected reward to the expected cost. It also updates the set of active arms, 𝑮ρ+1j=𝑮ρj\𝑩ρjsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝜌1𝑗\superscriptsubscript𝑮𝜌𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑩𝜌𝑗\boldsymbol{G}_{\rho+1}^{j}=\boldsymbol{G}_{\rho}^{j}\backslash\boldsymbol{B}_{\rho}^{j}. The process continues for R𝑅R rounds to eliminate K−1𝐾1K-1 arms. The remaining arm k∗superscript𝑘k^{*} is the optimal one for the scalarization function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j}, so the algorithm includes it in the set of optimal arms 𝑰S∗subscriptsuperscript𝑰𝑆\boldsymbol{I}^{*}_{S}. The cycle repeats for all the scalarization functions to identify all optimal arms. The computational complexity of the S-C-G-Seq-El algorithm is 𝒪​(S​R​n)𝒪𝑆𝑅𝑛\mathcal{O}(SRn).

Theorem 1.

VIII Numerical Results

We consider a 111 km ×\times 111 km square-shaped sensor network. The sensors’ distribution is a Poisson point process with density λ=150𝜆150\lambda=150 sensor/km2. The ground server is at the center. The locations of the four available UAVs are determined by the circle packing theorem. The UAVs’ altitude is H=230𝐻230H=230 m, which is optimal for the circle packing radius R=250𝑅250R=250 m [35]. In this example, we use the MNIST dataset for image classification for the FL training in the 4-UAV network. Each UAV collects the MNIST data samples from the active sensors and engages in a FL image classification task. We adapt the FL convolutional neural network parameters from reference [4]. Table II lists the urban environment and transmission parameters.
The wireless sensors have 555 cm2 photovoltaic panels for harvesting solar energy. Given that the energy arrival rate in a sunny day is 151515 mW/cm2 [40], each sensor harvests energy at a rate of 7775mW. A sensor will transmit using the harvest-then-use energy harvesting scheme if it harvests at least ET=100subscript𝐸𝑇100E_{T}=100 mJ and is covered by a UAV.
Each UAV can take two beamwidths, namely, θ=41∘𝜃superscript41\theta=41^{\circ} and 47.39∘superscript47.3947.39^{\circ}, which correspond to coverage radii 200200200 m and 250250250 m, respectively. Thus, the bi-objective MAB problem has 24=16superscript24162^{4}=16 arms, arm 1 has the configuration 𝜽1={41∘,41∘,41∘,41∘}subscript𝜽1superscript41superscript41superscript41superscript41\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}=\{41^{\circ},41^{\circ},41^{\circ},41^{\circ}\}, arm 2 is 𝜽2={41∘,41∘,41∘,47.39∘}subscript𝜽2superscript41superscript41superscript41superscript47.39\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}=\{41^{\circ},41^{\circ},41^{\circ},47.39^{\circ}\} and so on. Fig. 2 illustrates the simulated network for four different arms, i.e., beamwidth configurations.
Let 𝝁1,…,𝝁16subscript𝝁1…subscript𝝁16\boldsymbol{\mu}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{\mu}_{16} be the normalized average reward vectors of the 16 arms. A reward vector 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k} dominates vector 𝝁αsubscript𝝁𝛼\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha} if 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k} is not worse than 𝝁αsubscript𝝁𝛼\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha} in all objectives and 𝝁ksubscript𝝁𝑘\boldsymbol{\mu}_{k} is strictly better than 𝝁αsubscript𝝁𝛼\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\alpha} in at least one objective. The reward vectors that are not dominated by any other reward vector are optimal and they form the Pareto front. For benchmarking, we find the optimal reward set 𝒪∗superscript𝒪\mathcal{O}^{*} and the corresponding arm set 𝒜∗superscript𝒜\mathcal{A}^{*} by finding the empirical normalized average rewards of all arms over 5×1065superscript1065\times 10^{6} iterations. Then, the set of non-dominated arms is found by exhaustive search, i.e., by comparing the arms’ reward vectors to find the dominance relations. The same Pareto front was obtained using the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II). Fig. 3(a) shows the normalized average reward for all the arms, the set of non-dominated average rewards 𝒪∗superscript𝒪\mathcal{O}^{*} corresponds to the optimal arm set 𝒜∗={1,3,7,8,15,16}superscript𝒜13781516\mathcal{A}^{*}=\{1,3,7,8,15,16\}. To interpret this result in terms of the network parameters, Table III transforms the normalized average reward of each arm to the corresponding average number of covered sensors N¯𝜽subscript¯𝑁𝜽\bar{N}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} and the average maximum delay denoted by T¯maxsubscript¯𝑇\bar{T}_{\max}. Clearly, arms 1 and 16 are optimal because they minimize the maximum delay and maximize the coverage, respectively. Arms 3, 7 ,8, and 15 achieve a tradeoff between the two objectives. However, arm 9, for example, is not optimal since arm 7 achieves a higher coverage and less delay.

Fig. 3(b) shows the fraction of time each arm is played in 5×1065superscript1065\times 10^{6} rounds. Pareto UCB1 pulls the optimal arms fairly. For the scalarized bi-objective UCB1 algorithm, we use 11 uniformly spaced weights, wj∈{[1,0],[0.9,0.1],…,[0,1]}superscript𝑤𝑗100.90.1…01w^{j}\in\{[1,0],[0.9,0.1],\dots,[0,1]\}. The LinS method cannot find all the optimal arms in the non-convex Pareto front because there is no set of weights that describes all optimal reward vectors. Consequently, the algorithm exploits arms 1 and 16 significantly more frequently than the other optimal arms. The ChebS performs better than LinS in exploiting the optimal arms as it can find the optimal arms in a non-convex Pareto front. This fact also appears in terms of the unfairness regret Fig. 3(c). Fig. 3(d) shows the average regret. The Pareto UCB1 algorithm has a low average regret as it finds all optimal arms and plays them fairly. In contrast, the LinS algorithm incurs a large average regret as it fails to find all the optimal arms. ChebS has a lower average regret than LinS as it performs better in finding the optimal arms.

The multi-objective optimization problem returns a set of optimal arms. However, the server selects one of them as the UAVs’ beamwidths based on its preference and the application. To show this, we consider a 4-UAV network that is similar to the one described above, with the exception that the sensors’ locations follow an inhomogeneous Poisson distribution with density λ​(x,y)=150​(x2+y2)𝜆𝑥𝑦150superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦2\lambda(x,y)=150(x^{2}+y^{2}) sensors/km2. Among the 16 arms, six are optimal. Fig. 4 shows the optimal arms with their coverage and maximum delay. As expected, the circle packing placement (arm 16) maximizes coverage; nevertheless, it might not fit the FL process as it prolongs the delay. Generally, using any of these 6 arms is optimal as opposed to the sub-optimal arms.

The next example shows the performance of the S-C-G-Seq-El algorithm using the network of the first numerical example and linear scalarization. The S-C-G-Seq-El algorithm starts by estimating the budget based on the maximum energy consumed by the UAVs per global round when the UAVs take the largest beamwidths. Then, the optimal arms are obtained by finding the best arm for each scalarization function. The performance analysis is here more complicated than the single objective case [27, 28] because there are multiple performance measures.
In Fig. 5(a) -Fig. 5(c), we aim to find the arms that maximize the expected reward to the expected cost ratio for three instances of the S-C-G-Seq-El, S-Succ-Rej, S-N-Seq-EL with p=2𝑝2p=2, and S-Seq-Halv using linear scalarization. The prefix (S-) stands for scalarization to indicate that this is a bi-objective problem. Here, the optimal arms are arms 1, 3 and 15. Fig. 5(a) shows the unfairness regret. Although both algorithms eliminate one arm every round, the S-Succ-Rej has a lower unfairness regret than S-N-Seq-EL. This is because, in the first rounds when most arms are still available, S-Succ-Rej plays the arms longer than S-N-Seq-El, leaving less budget for the following rounds which results in higher fairness. Fig. 5(b) shows the instantaneous Pareto regret given by Δkj=fj​(𝑿¯k∗)c¯k∗−fj​(𝑿¯k)c¯ksuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑗superscript𝑓𝑗subscriptbold-¯𝑿superscript𝑘subscript¯𝑐superscript𝑘superscript𝑓𝑗subscriptbold-¯𝑿𝑘subscript¯𝑐𝑘\Delta_{k}^{j}=\frac{f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\bar{X}}_{k^{*}})}{\bar{c}_{k^{*}}}-\frac{f^{j}(\boldsymbol{\bar{X}}_{k})}{\bar{c}_{k}}, where k∗superscript𝑘k^{*} is the optimal arm under fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j}, averaged on all scalarization functions. The S-N-Seq-El with p=2𝑝2p=2 has the lowest Pareto regret, followed by Seq-Halv which implies that eliminating half of the arms in each round does not necessarily result in a higher Pareto regret. Fig. 5(c) shows the probability of discarding the optimal arm for a given scalarization function, averaged over all scalarization functions. The three algorithms are effective in finding the optimal arms as they have a low error probability.
Our proposed algorithm considers the arms’ energy cost to ensure that the recommended UAV configuration is energy efficient. But the algorithm can be used to find the arms that maximize the expected reward without considering the cost, i.e., when all arms have a unitary cost. Fig. 5(d) -Fig. 5(f) show the results for the latter case. The discussion here is similar to the previous case except for higher Pareto regret and error probability. This is because when the arms’ cost was considered, arm 1 had a much higher ratio of expected reward to expected energy cost compared to the others arms, and the algorithm was capable of finding it with a low error probability despite the limited budget. However, for the case of unitary cost, the sub-optimality gap was smaller, leading to more errors in finding the optimal arm for a given scalarization function fjsuperscript𝑓𝑗f^{j}. Still, the low Pareto regret shows that the reward of the recommended arm is close to the optimal one.

IX Conclusion

In this paper, the performance of FL in UAV-enhanced wireless networks was optimized under uncertainty about channels’ quality, sensors’ distribution, and transmission probability. Each UAV collects data from the sensors in its coverage regions and operates as an FL client. As the network parameters significantly affect the FL performance, we jointly optimize two conflicting objectives, maximizing the sensor coverage and minimizing the FL convergence time. We proposed a solution based on MO-MAB with two variations, Pareto UCB1, and linear multi-objective UCB1. Besides, we developed an efficient solution, S-C-G-Seq-El, based on the best arm identification concept. We define the best arm as one that maximizes the expected reward to the expected energy-cost ratio for an energy-efficient solution. Numerical results show that Pareto UCB1 performs better than the linearly-scalarized UCB1 algorithm in finding the optimal arms and playing them almost equally frequently. Then, we investigated the performance of three instances of the S-C-G-Seq-El algorithm. Although S-Seq-Halv removes half of the arms in every round, its performance concerning unfairness and Parto regret is comparable to S-Succ-Rej and S-N-Seq-El, which eliminate one arm per round. Our proposed solution has a wide range of applications in communication networks, as most optimization problems in such a network are intrinsically multi-objective. An example is client selection in FL to jointly optimize the convergence time, accuracy, and energy consumption.

X-D Proof of Theorem 43

At the end of the round, the algorithm removes the set 𝑩ρsubscript𝑩𝜌\boldsymbol{B}_{\rho} of the worst bρsubscript𝑏𝜌b_{\rho} arms. Accordingly, an error occurs when the algorithm recommends a sub-optimal arm by the end of the R𝑅R rounds [28], i.e.,

ℙ​[𝑮R+1≠{k∗}]=ℙ​[k∗∈∪ρ=1R𝑩ρ]=∑ρ=1R∑Gρℙ​[k∗∈𝑩ρ|𝑮ρ=Gρ]​ℙ​[𝑮ρ=Gρ].ℙdelimited-[]subscript𝑮𝑅1superscript𝑘ℙdelimited-[]superscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑅subscript𝑩𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑅subscriptsubscript𝐺𝜌ℙdelimited-[]superscript𝑘conditionalsubscript𝑩𝜌subscript𝑮𝜌subscript𝐺𝜌ℙdelimited-[]subscript𝑮𝜌subscript𝐺𝜌\mathbb{P}\left[\boldsymbol{G}_{R+1}\neq\{k^{*}\}\right]=\mathbb{P}[k^{*}\in\cup_{\rho=1}^{R}\boldsymbol{B}_{\rho}]=\sum_{\rho=1}^{R}\sum_{G_{\rho}}\mathbb{P}[k^{*}\in\boldsymbol{B}_{\rho}|\boldsymbol{G}_{\rho}=G_{\rho}]\mathbb{P}[\boldsymbol{G}_{\rho}=G_{\rho}]. Note that at every selection round, the reward and the energy cost are dependent as they both depend on 𝜽ksubscript𝜽𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} and Ti,Lsubscript𝑇𝑖LT_{i,\text{L}}. However, the rewards obtained at different times are independent of each other, and so are the energy costs. Hence, the Hoeffding inequality still applies in (62).

ℙ​[𝑮R+1≠{k∗}]≤∑ρ=1R∑k=gρ−bρ+1gρexp⁡(−2​nρ​(μk∗X−ϵ​μk∗c)2(ϵ+1)2)+exp⁡(−2​nρ​(−μ(k)X+ϵ​μ(k)c)2(ϵ+1)2).ℙdelimited-[]subscript𝑮𝑅1superscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝑔𝜌subscript𝑏𝜌1subscript𝑔𝜌2subscript𝑛𝜌superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋superscript𝑘italic-ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐superscript𝑘2superscriptitalic-ϵ122subscript𝑛𝜌superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋𝑘italic-ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘2superscriptitalic-ϵ12\mathbb{P}\left[\boldsymbol{G}_{R+1}\neq\{k^{*}\}\right]\leq\sum_{\rho=1}^{R}\sum_{k=g_{\rho}-b_{\rho}+1}^{g_{\rho}}\exp\left(-\frac{2n_{\rho}\left(\mu^{X}_{k^{*}}-\epsilon\mu^{c}_{k^{*}}\right)^{2}}{(\epsilon+1)^{2}}\right)+\exp\left(-\frac{2n_{\rho}\left(-\mu^{X}_{(k)}+\epsilon\mu^{c}_{(k)}\right)^{2}}{(\epsilon+1)^{2}}\right). (63)

By substituting the value of ϵ=μk∗X+μ(k)Xμk∗c+μ(k)citalic-ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘\epsilon=\frac{\mu^{X}_{k^{*}}+\mu^{X}_{(k)}}{\mu^{c}_{k^{*}}+\mu^{c}_{(k)}} in (63) and rearranging the terms, (63) reduces to

ℙ​[𝑮R+1≠{k∗}]≤∑ρ=1R∑k=gρ−bρ+1gρ2​exp⁡(−2​nρ​(μk∗X​μ(k)c−μk∗c​μ(k)Xμk∗X+μ(k)X+μk∗c+μ(k)c)2).ℙdelimited-[]subscript𝑮𝑅1superscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝑔𝜌subscript𝑏𝜌1subscript𝑔𝜌22subscript𝑛𝜌superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐superscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝑘2\mathbb{P}\left[\boldsymbol{G}_{R+1}\neq\{k^{*}\}\right]\leq\sum_{\rho=1}^{R}\sum_{k=g_{\rho}-b_{\rho}+1}^{g_{\rho}}2\exp\left(-2n_{\rho}\left(\frac{\mu^{X}_{k^{*}}\mu^{c}_{(k)}-\mu^{c}_{k^{*}}\mu^{X}_{(k)}}{\mu^{X}_{k^{*}}+\mu^{X}_{(k)}+\mu^{c}_{k^{*}}+\mu^{c}_{(k)}}\right)^{2}\right).
